issues.description: The problem statement and the template define the addParent method as addParent(Person person, Person parent) (i.e., first parameter = the child/person to be updated, second = parent to add). The solution implementation declares the method with the parameters reversed: addParent(Person parent, Person person). Although both parameters share the same type and thus compile, this swaps the semantic meaning of the positional arguments. The rest of the code (PersonResource, tests, and the problem description) call addParent(person, parent) (child first, parent second). Because the solution method treats the first parameter as the parent and the second as the person, this causes a semantic mismatch that will confuse students and produce incorrect behavior if they follow the template/specification or compare to the solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution method signature and implementation with the problem statement and template: declare addParent(Person person, Person parent) (first parameter = child/person to update, second = parent to add) and ensure the method adds 'parent' to 'person.getParents()' and saves 'person'. Alternatively, if the reversed parameter order was intentional, update the template, problem statement, PersonResource calls and tests consistently to use that order — but the simplest fix is to change the solution signature/parameter names back to (Person person, Person parent) and adjust variable names in the implementation accordingly.

issues.description: The problem statement and the template define the service method as addParent(Person person, Person parent) (child first, parent second). In the solution repository the method signature is reversed: addParent(Person parent, Person person). Call sites (PersonResource) and tests call addParent(person, parent) (child, parent). Because both parameters are of the same type (Person), this positional swap is not a compile-time type error but changes the semantic meaning of the arguments and creates a confusing mismatch between the described requirement, the starter code, and the reference implementation. Students mapping the problem requirements to the solution (or to the resource call sites) may be misled about which parameter is the child vs. the parent, increasing extraneous cognitive load and risking incorrect behavior.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution implementation use the same parameter order and naming as the problem description and template: change the solution's method signature to public Person addParent(Person person, Person parent) and update the implementation to reference the parameters accordingly (e.g., check person.getParents() and add parent to person.getParents()). This aligns the reference implementation with the starter code, resource call sites, and the exercise description, removing the positional-argument confusion.
